reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBack in the days before the invention of the quantum holocube capacitor (that is, pre-2053) computers had limited random access memory. To cope with this, software engineers designed technologies such as only loading levels when you enter them" and "not spawning four processes to play a 2d platformer". Thankfully
date: these constraints on a developer's artistic vision no longer apply. Now you can marvel at game over screens as soon as you start the tutorial. What an age we live in!\n\n-- Sent from my iNeuroUplink"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm extremely disappointed about the condition of this game. I realize that it's still in early access, but according to the news on the store page, full launch is expected by April 2016. It's because of this fact, and the posts indicating patches and updates that I decided that this was finally the time to take a look at it. I had really high hopes, even though I was expecting a minor glitch or two.

What I found instead was a game that I simply cannot play. Firstly, the game does not have full controller support, as indicated. At best, it's got partial support. I was unable to start the game, or even go to full-screen, without using the mouse. The menu didn't function correctly, and it appeared as if perhaps this was one of the features that had not yet been finished.

I began with the tutorial option, but it didn't work for me, so I decided to just try the play option. Again, I had to use the mouse to begin the game with Book 1
date:
and when the game did start, I experienced several difficulties and oddities.

Firstly, the screen would waver, like a mirror image or looking through water. I have no idea if this is intentional or because of a design issue, but it made it impossible for me to see my character and what I was doing. All the while, though, this side-scrolling platformer is continuing to move, so that resulted in sudden death."

The next thing I noticed was a sudden slowing of animations and movement on the screen. This most often occurred for me while my character was in motion or in the air in mid-jump.

I attempted several times to finish the first level but couldn't
recommended: so I had the idea to see if I could go to "Book 2" without having actually finished "Book 1." It turned out that I could
hoursPlayed: though it's probably not a good thing that this was possible. Again turning to the mouse to launch the level
voteText: I made a few successful jumps
helpfulPercent: popped off a couple shots with my gun and noticed that the shots seemed to be moving much slower than they probably should. I figured that I could deal with that and just kept jumping
votesHelpful: determined to play this game that I'd been anticipating.\n\nThis is when my screen started wavering yet again and then a very odd thing happened. I'd landed onto a lower building
votesFunny: the building disappeared. My character remained stuck in an odd position in the middle of my screen
commentsCount: and everything just froze. I couldn't believe I was actually seeing what I was seeing
column16: so I took a screen shot and then tried to restart the level.\n\nUnfortunately
column17: I was unable to use any of the controls or the mouse. I hit Alt+Tab and closed the game screen
column18: but even that didn't work. Next
column20: but I kept getting an error message that Steam couldn't close because Guardians of Victoria was running. With no game screen to close
column21: and no option to force quit
column22: I had no choice but to reboot in order to regain control over my laptop.\n\nI can't even express how disappointed I am. I love indie games
column25: so I was truly excited about this game. I can see from some of the posts that the developer has had quite a struggle with this game
column26: and I sympathize with that. Unfortunately
column28: I really cannot recommend the game in it's current state. I will
column30: invite the developer to reach out to me when the game is truly finished. At that point
column31:
I will absolutely give the game another try and revise my review.


*Review written exclusively for Good Games Giveaways & Reviews"

reviewText:
If you load the game you get an award for waiting through the loading process as it takes so long.

If you can figure out how to start a level, you win the starter" award for being able to navigate the bad graphics.

When you start the first level you can get an award for restarting (or respawning after dying) and watching the instructions 100 times.

If you jump over the first two red buildings and then fall off the blue building

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't really like to bash games on here to this extent but after the experience I have just had trying to play the game I think people should know how it currently plays.

This game is *very* unfinished despite claiming to be on patch 1.3 at the moment. The menus have overlapping music tracks, the buttons take 5 or 6 attempts to click, when I finally got into the game the screen stretched in weird ways over itself before dumping me onto a screen in which I could only look left and right (Tried using all three sets of movement controls from the controls screen).

On my second attempt to play the game I was able to move! (I think jumping first set it off)

I have a video below of my second attempt at playing the game to back up my claims (Yes I know I'm not very good at it, I was mainly surprised that it let me move after the first time)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

--Updated review as of 6th january--

TL;DR Not recommended in current state: RAM usage problem + unfinished

--

Played a bit, tried tutorial and 3 levels

The main problem is still there. Game uses ~2 gb RAM in main menu and scales up to 3-4 gb while playing levels.

Here are some more significant problems:
- game is lagging as hell through levels. This is unacceptable for any game, but especially for one, based on precise jumping and timing
- same goes for music and game sounds - they're lagging along with visuals. Also, there's a bug with water" platforms - using them more than 3-4 times causes "water" sounds overlapping and stopping all the music and game sounds
- various bugs (inability to jump
hoursPlayed: etc)\n- some poor desicions with level design: too colorful backgrounds causing text to be unreadable
voteText: no clear distinction between surfaces you can and can't stand on
helpfulPercent: tips on the bottom of the screen while playing (you probably wouldn't read 'em because game is fast-paced)\n- general feeling of incompleteness
votesHelpful: no unified visual and audio style (for example
votesTotal: half of the music is standard MacLeod themes

EDIT: 1/28/2016

Per the Game Devs request, I am taking a second look at the game.

For the longest time the game was literally unplayable due to technical issues. This seems to been resolved and the game is now, by definition, playable.

However, it is still not fun at all and the UI is literally the worst I have ever seen.

To the devs, you should scratch all UI work to date and completely outsource that aspect to a competent UI artist.

There IS a small amount of fun to be had here. But theres emphasis on small".

The devs appear to be active
date: but I cannot recommend this at all in its current state."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my original review, i wrote that 4 gb of ram weren't enough to play this game, however, that changed: the developer has patched the game and it runs much better now.
With this i was able to play more of the game, so here's a more detailed review:

Gameplay: despiste being a little bit confusing at first, it gets nice after a few minutes of practice.

Animations: the animations are quite nice, but some of the environment animations are quite messy.

Interface: the in-game HUD is messy, same thing with the Menu, as i found quite confusing to navigate trought the options, controls, etc.

Performance: the game runs much better now, however it can still freezes for a few seconds in the menu.

This game as pottential, what the dev needs to do is to apply his ideias properly.

Avoid it for now, or buy it on sale.

Early Access Review

This game is great if you're looking for something on steam to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you off to no end.

It takes most of your computer resources, holds them hostage, and does nothing visible with them (who knows what it does in the background though). There are no redeeming qualities to this game, after you get through the stupid start up, and finally get the game running, you will get to a game that is outclasses by free flash games written as highschool projects. The gameplay is boring, and tepid. The soundtrack and most of the effects (even as early as the starter screen) are annoying, tasteless and gross.

Do not pay for this game, it is not worth any price no matter how low.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not so much a runner as an auto-scrolling platformer - think of the Mario levels where the screen keeps moving to the right, and you lose a life if you're left behind.

There are three characters to choose from - a Princess Peach-a-like who glides and attacks with her parasol, a pirate who can double jump and stab baddies with her cutlass and an Irish Steampunk version of FFVII's Barrett, whose gun arm works like a turret.

There are some excellent songs in the soundtrack, and the art is mostly charming.

IF you choose to buy the game now, know that it's in VERY early access.  Some of the basics are missing - menus don't work as they should, control is a bit sluggish, some enemies are unintentionally immortal, many key animations aren't in place yet, most levels are missing and so on.

Despite that, the groundwork is there for a true gem, and I think the current price (about $3 USD) is fair for what's currently in place.

The devs have shown themselves to be very responsive to feedback, and have already massively updated the game in response to user input in the few days it's been out.

This is definitely one to watch.

Recommended for anyone who likes the idea of the game and is willing to put up with a VERY early access product. HIGHLY recommended for those who enjoy giving constructive feedback.
